column2: Vassalize the Dorados
With the Mexican Empire revived, the Dorados would willingly serve a sufficiently wealthy and pious Emperor - granted their ancient rights be respected...
Restore the Mexican Empire to Glory

If key regions of the Empire and their the caudillos be brought to heel, the world must then truly recognize the Mexican Empire as a dominant force and the rightful continuation of the old, antidiluvian empire.
The Mexican Miracle!

A true relic of the past, the Mexican Empire has long claimed continuity with the ancient republic. However, centuries of mismanagement and religious strife led to the fracturing of the Empire. Many had believed that Mexico's time had finally come to an end. \n[Root.GetTitledFirstName] has proven them wrong. [Root.GetSubjectPronounCap] has brought the rogue realms of the caudillos back into the fold of the Empire and has brought a stability to the region not seen since Julián the Great. \nAlthough there is still territory left to be reclaimed and wars that have not yet been won, one thing is certain - Mexico is back.
Sigo siendo el rey...
Yo soy mexicano, mi tierra es bravía
They have unleashed a tiger, let's see if they can control it.
Better to die on your feet, than live on your knees!
Make Mexico City the Capital
Mexico City, the "Place in the Navel of the Moon", is the crown jewel of La República and its ancient namesake. If you so wish, you may restore it as the capital of the Mexican Empire.
Mexico City once more becomes the seat of imperial power.
column3: Rome est une fois de plus la capitale du pouvoir impérial.
column4: Rom wird einmal mehr der Sitz der kaiserlichen Macht.
column6: Roma vuelve a ser la sede del poder imperial.

column2: Reconquest of Jalisco
$ORDER$Reconquest War for Jalisco
§Y[Root.GetTitledName]§! can start a war to oust the infidels from the region of §Y[k_jalisco.GetBaseName]§!, and retake all provinces in the area held by §Y$TARGET$§!.
Reconquest of Colima
$ORDER$Reconquest War for Colima
§Y[Root.GetTitledName]§! can start a war to oust the infidels from the region of §Y[k_colima.GetBaseName]§!, and retake all provinces in the area held by §Y$TARGET$§!.
Reconquest of Michoacan
$ORDER$Reconquest War for Michoacan
§Y[Root.GetTitledName]§! can start a war to oust the infidels from the region of §Y[k_michoacan.GetBaseName]§!, and retake all provinces in the area held by §Y$TARGET$§!.
Reconquest of Mixteca
$ORDER$Reconquest War for Mixteca
§Y[Root.GetTitledName]§! can start a war to oust the infidels from the region of §Y[k_mixteca.GetBaseName]§!, and retake all provinces in the area held by §Y$TARGET$§!.
Reconquest of Oaxaca
$ORDER$Reconquest War for Oaxaca
§Y[Root.GetTitledName]§! can start a war to oust the infidels from the region of §Y[k_oaxaca.GetBaseName]§!, and retake all provinces in the area held by §Y$TARGET$§!.
Reconquest of Mexican Coast
$ORDER$Reconquest War for Mexican Coast
§Y[Root.GetTitledName]§! can start a war to oust the infidels from the region of §Y[d_veracruz.GetBaseName]§!, and retake all provinces in the area held by §Y$TARGET$§!.
Reconquest of Valley of Mexico
$ORDER$Reconquest War for Valley of Mexico
§Y[Root.GetTitledName]§! can start a war to oust the infidels from the region of §Y[d_mexico.GetBaseName]§!, and retake all provinces in the area held by §Y$TARGET$§!.
Reconquest of Bajio
$ORDER$Reconquest War for Bajio
§Y[Root.GetTitledName]§! can start a war to oust the infidels from the region of §Y[k_bajio.GetBaseName]§!, and retake all provinces in the area held by §Y$TARGET$§!.
Reconquest of Gran Chichimeca
$ORDER$Reconquest War for Gran Chichimeca
§Y[Root.GetTitledName]§! can start a war to oust the infidels from the region of §Y[k_gran_chichimeca.GetBaseName]§!, and retake all provinces in the area held by §Y$TARGET$§!.
Reconquest of Huasteca and Puebla
$ORDER$Reconquest War for Huasteca and Puebla

§Y[Root.GetTitledName]§! can start a war to oust the infidels from the region of §Y[d_huasteca.GetBaseName]§! and §Y[d_peubla.GetBaseName]§!, and retake all provinces in the area held by §Y$TARGET$§!.
The Cristero Wars have Begun\n
Cristero Kings

For centuries now, rightful Mexican land has been slipping away to heathenry. The Crusaders of Cristo Rey have decided to take a more active stance in the battle for the soul of Mexico, and have agreed on a new doctrine of just war to accomplish this goal. This signals a new era of large scale holy wars - a new Cristiada has begun.
Viva Cristo Rey!

The heroic port city of Veracruz has fallen to heathenry and the Valley of Mexico itself is now vulnerable to conquest. In response, the Crusaders of Cristo Rey have decided to take a more active stance in the battle for the soul of Mexico, and have agreed on a new doctrine of just war to accomplish this goal. This signals a new era of large scale holy wars - a new Cristiada has begun.

The great city of Mexico has fallen to heathenry, marking the lowest point in the history of the Empire. In response, the Crusaders of Cristo Rey have resolved to retake the entire Mexican Empire by any means necessary, and have agreed on a new doctrine of just war to accomplish this goal. This signals a new era of large scale holy wars - a new Cristiada has begun.

The Mexican Empire has been crumbling from within to those who do not believe in the power of Christ and his Saints. In response, the Crusaders of Cristo Rey have decided to take a more active stance against heathen, and have agreed on a new doctrine of just war to accomplish this goal. This signals a new era of large scale holy wars - a new Cristiada has begun.
Start preparing a campaign against the heathens within Mexico, to claim parts of the Mexican Empire for the Virgin. A large undertaking like this can usually only be done once a lifetime.
Find a fitting dynasty member to become a beneficiary for my conquests in Mexico.
Set §Y[Root.GetTitledName]§! as a beneficiary for my conquests in Mexico.
§Y[Root.GetTitledName]§! will no longer be my beneficiary for my conquests in Mexico.
I can sell my services against the other Saint Cultists for a sum of money, if §Y[Root.GetTitledName]§! is willing to pay.
I can ask §Y[Root.GetTitledName]§! for help against the other Saint Cultist invaders, in return for a small sum of money.
Chapulín blood of [Root.GetFirstName]
Known for both fighting against and helping the heathens throughout the Cristiada, as one of the greatest generals of our times.
Cristero Blood of [Root.GetFirstName]
Known for being one of the most important characters in the new Cristiada.
It seems I have waited too long, as my men and all my preparation starts to come apart. It seems people lost faith in my plans, when I did not start any wars for the soul of Mexico.

Magnanimous [Root.GetTitledName]

Your plans to claim Mexico for the Virgin inspires me to take up arms as well, and I will support your efforts to the best of my ability.

Your ally,
[From.GetTitledName]

After leading troops on both sides of the wars raging throughout the Empire of Mexico, I seem to have grown quite the reputation among the local peasants and soldiers on both sides.

Though some would consider me a chapulín - or grasshopper - that changes sides when the opportunity strikes, my prowess in war has made me a hero among most, and revered among the populace. Some would even go as far as to call me a folk hero.

Surely, my actions must have been righteous, seeing all the responses. I have often wondered if it would all be worth it in the end, and it is a joyous occasion to see all my hard work has paid off.
The Hero Cristero

I have fought for the faith several times these recent years, to claim the Empire of Mexico as a true vanguard for the Virgin and her followers.

Though Mexico was once a bastion of decadent practices by those who had reasserted their ancient heathen beliefs in the chaos after the Event, we have once again united them in the name of Cristo Rey. Step by step, we have regained what is rightfully ours.

The Empire of Mexico will once again be independent of invaders, united in principles, and under the Blessed Virgin. We will make sure of it.

To the greedy [Root.GetTitledName]

Your despicable offer disgusts me. I hope to see you at the battlefield next, so I can cut you down together with the rest of the heathens.

Signed,
[From.GetTitledName]

[Root.GetTitledName]

Your prowess in war is well known throughout Mexico, and I would like to offer your a sum of gold for your services in the current Cristero War.

Signed,
[From.GetTitledName]

There will probably be men showing up to fight for the faith in the upcoming wars for Mexico, but I could invest some money into spreading the message far and wide to attract more well trained troops.

A year has passed since I started my preparations for the Cristiada, and I am sure that whoever wanted to take part would have arrived by now. Now all that remains is to find a place to point my newfound allies towards.
The Cristiada

As the last in a long line of attempts to try to reassert the authority of the Empire of Mexico under Cristo Rey, [From.GetTitledName] has begun preparing [From.GetHerHis] troops and looking for allies for a new Mexican campaign. Trying to restore Mexico to the Blessed Virgin, [From.GetTitledFirstName] has spent a noticeable amount of resources and sent out a call to gather troops from all around the region.\n\nWith the Cristeros planning for war, the other faiths have started assembling their troops to defend themselves. It is only a matter of months, or maybe a year, before the two sides will clash together once more, desperately trying to claw their way to more land in Mexico.
¡Viva Cristo Rey!
The Christian rabble does not belong here.
Rise of Mexico

With the rise of the [e_mexico.GetFullName], the Empire of Mexico has once again come under total control of the [From.Religion.GetGroupName]. There was a long struggle between the different faiths occupying the region, but the [From.Religion.GetGroupName] believers have finally conquered their adversaries.\n\nWith the struggle of the two sides finally put to rest, Mexico can finally start looking forward to a peaceful future, free of the religious wars that have raged through on now for centuries.
Mexico will be the center of our faith.
End of the Cristiada

Not even the isthmus of Tehuantepec has been safe from the Cristero conquest of Mexico. The final bastions of the other faiths in the region has fallen, now only the followers of the Virgin are left.\n\nWith Mexico finally restored to the faithful, the disunity of the empire has ended, and peace has been restored. Once more the center of the faith, Mexico will surely play an important role in the region.

A minor noble has launched a campaign to start gathering troops to conquer parts of Mexico for the Blessed Virgin. [From.GetTitledFirstName] asks for my help in supporting [From.GetHerHim], and taking part in [From.GetHerHim] conquests. This is a great opportunity to drive the heathenry from Mexico.
The Arrival of Los San Patricios

A group of mysterious travelers has found their way to Mexico's shores, their eyes carrying the weight of a distant homeland oppressed by a powerful empire. Arriving with a familiar faith and an unwavering thirst for freedom, these foreigners seek solace in a new horizon, where they've forged a profound bond in the company of the Cristeros. Word of their alliance has begun to spread, breathing life into forgotten tales of days long gone. Named after their patron saint and the legendary battalion that once stood side-by-side with Mexico's ancestors against invaders from El Gabacho, the San Patricios have become a symbol of unity and strength. Shadows of bygone eras intertwine with the present as they stand shoulder to shoulder with the Mexicans, igniting a resurgence of bravery and resistance against tyranny.
¡Erin Go Bragh! ¡Viva Cristo Rey!
Foreign Christians from across the seas?
They flee opression to bring it to our land
The Patrons of El Sagrado Corazón

Followers of the faith of the Sacred Heart- Sagrado Corazón- all adhere to one general creed, but tend to favor a devotion to one specific saint within the Sacred Heart's pantheon. Although such devotions are often chosen early in life, it's not unheard of for a person to change their devotion later on.
I shall follow El Santo, the masked patron of justice and strength
Nuestra Señora, the Virgin of Guadalupe and mother of Mexico, is my patroness
I pray to Santa Muerte for a safe delivery to the Afterlife.

Your [GetFromRelation] [From.GetTitledFirstName] has entered into the realm of [Root.Religion.GetRandomGodName]. As a follower of Santa Muerte, [From.GetPossPronoun] death leaves you with certain responsibilities. You are expected to be involved in the funeral rites, which will ensure safe passage of [From.GetPossPronoun] soul as well as protecting those left behind.
I swear vengeance on [From.GetPossPronoun] killer!
This option is available because you know who killed your [GetFromRelation], and Santa Muerte will calm your mind and guide you to exacting your revenge.\n\n
La Santísima guides [From.GetPossPronoun] soul to heaven.
La Santísima protects and watches over all of us.

After hearing about the death of [FromFrom.GetTitledFirstName] at your hands, [From.GetTitledFirstName] has publicly sworn a vendetta against you. According to the rumors, [From.GetSubjectPronoun] will not rest until Santa Muerte guides you to the afterlife.
Reestablish the Archdiocese of Mexico
For hundreds of years, the faithful of the Sacred Heart have had no formal religious head. If a strong emperor sat on the throne once more, the faith could be consolidated with the crown...
The Orden de la Máscara have constructed a castle in [Root.GetName]!
La Orden de la Máscara

A new organization has formed in response to the continued encroachment of heathens and heretics onto rightful Mexican land. They call themselves La Orden de la Máscara - "The Order of the Mask" - and emulate El Santo by renouncing their identities and dawning masks to defend the innocents of Mexico against the heathen bandits. Many experienced soldiers have already joined their ranks.
Viva El Santo!

[relic_hunter.GetTitledFirstName] has returned, carrying with [relic_hunter.GetHerHim] an ancient codex. My [relic_hunter.GetJobTitle] ensures me that this was created by the ancestors of the Nahua people long before the even the foundation of the empire. Truly a great reminder of how our legacies extend throughout the ages.
Moctezuma's Headdress

[relic_hunter.GetTitledFirstName] has returned and brought with [relic_hunter.GetHerHim] an incredibly ancient and ornate headdress.\n[relic_hunter.GetSheHeCap] has proof that it once belonged to the legendary Moctezuma himself. The old stories speak the great vengeance and retribution he brought upon his enemies, hopefully with this headdress I can hope to embody that spirit and make my foes taste Moctezuma's revenge!\nSmiling as [relic_hunter.GetSheHe] sees the realization of the Headdress's great symbolic power creep onto your face, [relic_hunter.GetFirstName] waits patiently for you to speak.
Become a Cajita

Attempt to become a §YCajita§! - a worthy vessel for the divine spirits and saints so that they may interact directly with the mortal realm. To become a Cajita, one must be pure of soul and free from grave sins and then undergo a series of cleansing rituals to prepare their body for the spirit.
Must not have any sinful trait.
Cajita
This character is widely recognized by people of the Fidencista faith as a Cajita, or as the human vessel through which the greatest spirits and saints speak and act upon the world.
Divine Cajita

Fidencista nobles and peasants alike chafe beneath the yoke of an unworthy king. Why should they bend the knee to a common tyrant, when the materias tell them El Niño's inheritors can truly rule in God's will through mantling his most holy saints? To rule effectively, you must be declared a Cajita: the vessel through which a divine spirit or saint acts with a mandate to bring the necessary salvation to humanity.\n\n In order to become an inheritor to El Niño's legacy, you must cleanse yourself in a fast in the desert and bathe in blessed muds so that your heart is pure enough that the divine may enter.
I am ready to follow in the footsteps of El Niño.
Perhaps this is not a good idea.
Fasting in the Desert

You set out to the most barren lands of your realm, intent on living in complete austerity and fasting so that your soul may be purified and worthy enough such that it may serve as the most holy vessel of the saints.
I will resist temptation as Jesucristo did in the desert.

The days pass and your stomach grumbles, begging you to abandon your holy quest and with it, your chance of becoming a worthy vessel of the divine. As you traverse the landscape you realize you recognize the area and a town lays not that far from your current location. Surely they could spare a meal for their liege should they be called upon.
No, I must not abandon my holy mission.
I am merely human.
The Cajita cleansing rituals will be abandoned.

Weeks have now passed and the time fasting has taken a toll on your body. Still you meditate and maintain the discipline needed to complete your cleansing. However, you have the distinct feeling that your body may be failing. Already, you've noticed animals sensing your weakness - birds of prey and coyotes ready to feast on your carcass should it come to that.
It is too late for second guesses. Though I doubt I can carry on...

Your time of fasting is finished. You make your way back to the nearest town, prepared for your arrival with a large crowd of eager onlookers and your holiest Materias solemnly flanking a pool of mud. You enter the pool and allow yourself to be blessed and submerged by the Materias who then help you out of the pool so that you can continue crawling in humility to the holy shrine of the saints. At the shrine, you rise to light the votive candle of the spirit who will fill your soul with their grace.\n\nYou light the candle of...
A Vessel of the Divine
...Francisco Villa, the Centaur.
...El Niño Fidencio himself.
...Bejota, the Meritorious.
...Padre Toribio, the Martyr.
Unceremonious Return

The ordeal proved to be too much for you to handle. As you stumble to the nearest town, you are recieved by Materias awaiting your arrival and are quickly given the food and shelter your body severely lacked. Though your Materias reassure you that your failure does not mean that you are unworthy of rule, you can't help but notice the disappointment in their eyes as they watch you recover.
Perhaps I'll be given another opportunity... For now, I am thankful that I no longer have to suffer.
El Centauro del Norte

As the Cajita of the spirit of the Centaur, you feel drawn to be skilled in all aspects of war. You must be ready and willing to take the fight to the enemy and take chances on the battlefield. You must become like an angel of vengeance upon those who would abuse the downtrodden, showing no mercy more than they would show their lessers.\n\nIn battle you wear a bell-shaped hat and have sashes fitted with metal strips draped over your clothes as your only armor, trusting only Diosito and the spirit of the Centaur to save you.
the General
the Centaur
The Letters of Bejota

As the Cajita of the spirit of Bejota, you feel drawn to embody his vast administrative knowledge and just rule. Remembered in history as the "Benemérito de las Américas" - a title now laid claim to by the successors of the Empire of Mexico, Bejota truly was unyeilding in his upholding of the law even in the face of invasion. So too must you embody the diligence and sense of justice to uphold the peace and prosperity of your realm\n\nYour ceremonial garments are that of a fine black coat draped over your shoulders with a black ribbon tied around your neck.
the Meritorious
El Santo Niño Fidencio

As the Cajita of the spirit of El Niño himself, you feel you must be ready to provide for the people with great generosity and mystic energy. It is known that El Niño performed miracles of healing and even those who ruled came to visit for cures. While your duties may call you elsewhere, your people rely on you for their wellbeing and it is your most holy duty to see them taken care of.\n\nYour regalia a modest robe imprinted with the Sacred Heart of Jesus and a resplendent green cloak, covered in stars like that of the image of the Virgin of Guadalupe.
el Niño
Tlaloc's Chosen

As the Cajita of the spirit of Padre Toribio, you feel your faith strengthened as the people look to your for guidance and protection. As the vessel for the patron martyr of the displaced and migrant, it is expected that you maintain the unshakable faith of one who would die rather than renounce their beliefs and provide a beacon of hope to the people of your charge. \n\nThough there is no ceremonial regalia related to this saint, it is customary that you worship in the outskirts of your holdings, often in temporary places with those who rely on itinerant Materias.
The Protector
I feel my lifestyle changing.
I feel my habits changing.
I truly embody the Saint.
The preparations have been made and the players have been selected. It is time for the sacred ballgame to begin!
The game and its associated rituals have finally concluded, and the attendees begin to return home. The people must surely be pleased, and it is thanks in large part to my own wealth and diligence.
Recent Ballgame Match
This character has recently held a ritual game of "Fut", the sacred ballgame.

The Tonaltecs have sacrificed [From.GetTitledName] to their demon gods! After bringing [From.GetHerHim] to one of their new temple pyramids, their wicked priests placed [From.GetFirstName] on an altar and sliced [From.GetHerHim] open with a ceremonial dagger. They then tore out [From.GetHerHis] still beating heart to the cheers of their assembled warriors.
The Northern Cristiada

You have made your choice, the atomicist shrines have been looted, and the remaining Catholics of New Mexico and west Texas flock to your banners. You take one last look at your family, and silently wish that you could face this alone and they could be safe. Still, you know that this is beyond just you, and even them: This is for Christ the King.
Viva Cristo Rey!
Designate Tapado

The §YTapado§! - or the "covered one" - is the hidden heir apparent of the Mexican Empire. The Tapado must first be selected from a list of potential candidates and then revealed in the §Y"Destape"§! ceremony when the [ROOT.GetTitle] feels [ROOT.GetHerHis] end draws near.
Must be a powerful vassal, be on the imperial §Ycouncil§!, be a landed §Ycommander§!, have a §Yclaim§! on the Empire, or a §Yrelative§! of the current ruler
Must NOT have been disgraced as the Tapado\n
Relieve the Tapado so that a new one may be selected.

With the Tapado selected, the utmost discretion must be taken to maintain the secrecy of their identity. Should one learn of who he or she may be, the devious minds of the court of Mexico may seek to extort or plan their downfall. Instead, each must believe themselves to be the true Tapado up until the moment that the true heir is unveiled. Now you may begin to plan your succession, but be aware, if you call the "Destape" ceremony too early before your reign is ended, the illusion will be shattered and the powerful and connected may have enough time to try to place a selection of their own in the great Silla Presidencial as the next [FromFrom.GetTitle].
He who rushes ahead won't get his portrait in the mural...
La República and its stability are at stake and if I have doubts about the one who shall succeed me, that means I hadn't chosen wisely before.
I must reconsider my successor...
Destape Ceremony
The Unveiling Ceremony Begins
The Grand Unveiling
Choosing an Heir

The time has come for the great unveiling of El Tapado. The most powerful and influential figures of La República must now be gathered in the main hall of Chapultepec Castle to witness the ceremony, they must stand with [From.GetTitle]'s choice or plot and scheme to place one of their own as the true successor to La Silla Presidencial.
I should warm up my choosing finger.
No, this is premature...

The [FromFrom.GetTitle] is planning to reveal [FromFrom.GetHerHis] successor in a grand unveiling. The most powerful figures of the realm will now be gathered in the main hall of Chapultepec Castle to witness the ceremony. Everyone must now either stand with the [FromFrom.GetTitle]'s choice as tradition dictates or plot and scheme to try to place their own choice on the ancient and powerful Silla Presidencial.
Let us see who the [FromFrom.GetTitle] has named as [FromFrom.GetHerHis] successor

The most powerful of the political class gather into the chamber awaiting the great unveiling of the next heir to the Silla Presidencial. The crowd falls silent as the [FromFrom.GetTitle] enters the room, with bated breath all await the "Dedazo" - when the [FromFrom.GetTitle] will point to the one [FromFrom.GetSheHe] deems worthy to wear the Imperial Band. The [FromFrom.GetTitle] gives a brief, rehearsed speech and then points to [FromFrom.GetHerHis] chosen candidate, shaping the future of Mexico...
The moment has come!
The [FromFrom.GetTitle]'s finger is directly pointing toward you. You have been chosen to be the next in line to be the [FromFrom.GetTitle]!
I am at the service of La República.

The [FromFrom.GetTitle]'s finger comes to rest in front of [FromFrom.GetHerHis] chosen successor, [FROM.GetBestName]. Thus, the veil is lifted and all can see who has been chosen to rule after the current [FromFrom.GetTitle]. The lines will quickly be drawn. Should this "Destapado" be supported as the ancient tradition dictates? Or is another more worthy to lead?
The ancient tradition must be upheld
I will not suffer this fool on the Silla Presidencial!

My finger comes to rest in front of my chosen successor, [FROM.GetBestName]. Thus, the veil is lifted and all can see who has been chosen to rule after the current [Root.GetTitle]. The lines will quickly be drawn. Should this "Destapado" be supported as the ancient tradition dictates? or is another more worthy to lead? The chamber is emptied after the usual mingling and political schmoozing, yet the dust has yet to settle. Will my choice persevere as has according to tradition? or will it fall prey to political machinations?
Let us wait and see what becomes of this...

The chamber is emptied after the usual mingling and political schmoozing, yet the dust has yet to settle. Will this choice persevere as has according to tradition? or will it fall prey to political machinations?
Let us wait and see what becomes of this...
The grand Destape Ceremony has been cancelled due to war.
I guess we must wait and see who will be the next to lead...

The §YTapado§! - or the "covered one" - is the hidden heir apparent of the Mexican Empire. The Tapado must first be selected from a list of potential candidates and then revealed in the §Y"Destape"§! ceremony when the [ROOT.GetTitle] feels [ROOT.GetHerHis] end draws near. A truly worthy heir must be a powerful vassal, be on the imperial §Ycouncil§!, be a landed §Ycommander§!, have a §Yclaim§! on the Empire, or a cunning Benemérito might try to put a §Yrelative§! on La Silla Presidencial
It should be the most popular vassal.
It should be someone with strength to lead.
It should be someone of my own family.
I still need more time to decide...
You may select or relieve a Tapado of your choice with a targeted decision on the desired character at any time.
[Root.GetTitledName] made a pilgrimage to the city of Mexico.
I will visit the glorious city of Mexico, seat of the Empress of the Americas.
[Root.GetTitledName] made a pilgrimage to the El Cerro del Cubilete.
I will visit El Cerro del Cubilete and honor the martyrs and Cristo Rey.
[Root.GetTitledName] made a pilgrimage to Guadalajara.
I will visit Santa Inocencia in the great city of Guadalajara.
I seek a different place to go to...
[Root.GetTitledName] made a pilgrimage to the city of Zacatecas.
I will visit the ancient temples in the City of Silver Aristocrats, Zacatecas.
[Root.GetTitledName] made a pilgrimage to San Juan de los Lagos.
I will visit Nuestra Señora de San Juan de los Lagos in her church.
[Root.GetTitledName] made a pilgrimage to the city of Puebla.
I will visit the temples in the city of angels, Puebla.
[Root.GetTitledName] made a pilgrimage to the city of Cholula.
I will visit the city of three hundred and sixty-five churches, Cholula.
[Root.GetTitledName] made a pilgrimage to El Santuario del Señor de Chalma.
I will visit El Santuario del Señor de Chalma in the town of Chalma.
[Root.GetTitledName] made a pilgrimage to Lake Catemaco.
I will visit the city in Lake Catemaco, realm of La Santa Muerte.
[Root.GetTitledName] made a pilgrimage to Espinazo.
I will visit the tomb of El Niño Fidencio in Espinazo.
[Root.GetTitledName] made a pilgrimage to Cabo San Lucas.
I will visit the Sacred Arch in Cabo San Lucas.
My things are packed, everything is in order. I will go see the most sacred city in the continent.
Ciudad de México

You have arrived to the center of Mexico. You stand now in El Zócalo and in front of you is La Catedral Metropolitana, you enter it and immediately feel in another world. The beautiful crooked majestuosity of it all, it takes you aback, you almost crash with the flags and remains of the First Emperor.\nYou thought nothing would make your heart race more after that, but then you finally arrived to the great Explanada de Guadalupe just in front of the ancient Basilicas. You see thousands and thousands of pilgrims on their knees, they are doing penance so that Nuestra Señora de Guadalupe intercedes for them. Never before had you seen such a beautiful display of faith. You can feel the presence of Dios within all those people, and withing yourself as well.\nYou see the Basilica on the other side of the square, La Tilma de Juan Diego, La Virgen de Guadalupe, awaits you patiently inside. But you must not make her wait for you are only her humble child and she is the Empress of the Americas. Tears roll down your face.
I kneel, and on my knees I begin to walk towards the temple of my faith.
My things are packed, everything is in order. I will make the hike to meet Cristo Rey.
Cristo de la Montaña

You finally made your way to El Cerro del Cubilete, located not far from either Silao or León, and home to El Santuario de Cristo Rey. While the stone-paved road in the slopes of the mountain may be steep, the occasional glimpse of what awaits you at the top fills your body with stamina to push forwards.\nThe sanctuary is not the first monument of Cristo Rey to be erected in El Cerro del Cubilete, there used to be another one but a tyrannical ruler of Old Mexico destroyed it using dreadful weapons of the Old World. But Cristo Rey and the faith will never be broken and so the current monument stands were the previous one stood.\nYou have finally made it to the horseshoe shaped sanctuary, topped by a massive statue of Cristo Rey standing atop a globe shaped dome. Two angels flank him, each with a crown: one of martyrdom and one of glory.
The two crowns form one, for martyrdom guarantees glory. Viva Cristo Rey!
My things are packed, everything is in order. As the goats of old, I will make my way to Guadalajara.
Guadalajara, Guadalajara!

You have finally arrived at La Perla Tapatía. This ancient city and its surrounding towns have always been the cultural standard of Mexico, with its famed Charros, Mariachi, and Tequila. But it has also always had a significant religious importance as within the Guadalajara Cathedral lays in full view of the public one of the oldest relics in the continent, the body of Santa Inocencia, Roman virgin and martyr.\nThe legend holds that this beautiful child was victim of one of the early persecutions against Catholics when her father killed her after she shared with him her joy of having had her first communion. Her body arrived at Guadalajara from Sacred Rome itself centuries ago and through trials and tribulations, the bones of Santa Inocencia and the sculpted body in which they are protected, have remained safely within the city.\nYour mind wonders if you will be one of the lucky few who Santa Inocencia deems worthy enough to open her eyes to look at.
Take me to the Cathedral! No Charrería, nor Tequila for me… for the time being.
My things are packed, everything is in order. I am ready to follow the silver way to the silver city.
Zacatecas

You have finally arrived at Zacatecas, ancient city founded when the silver veins around it where discovered. The small town feel this venerable city retains, with its narrow hilly streets and simple one or two-storied buildings, is broken only by the massive churches that dominate over their respective barrios and the city’s skyline.\nBut none stand to rival the massive Cathedral Basilica of Zacatecas. Dedicated to La Virgen de la Asunción, the main facade is one of the most detailed in the entire world with a Churriguresque Baroque style in which Dios, as the Eternal father and as a statue of Jesucristo, presides over a collection of statues of Ángeles and Apóstoles that greet the faithful that are to enter the church. The inside is austere and somber, except for the altar which is made up of wooden prisms covered in gold in honour of La Virgen María and the saints.\nSuch beauty has left you speechless.
Dios guides the hands of us mere mortals when we construct his temples!
My things are packed, everything is in order. I will leave my Exvoto in the church alongside the other thousands there will surely be.
San Juan de los Lagos

Before you see either church or city, you see the pilgrims. Thousands upon thousands in group pilgrimages fill the roads towards the town. Many of them carry Exvotos, images, flowers, and other various offerings they are planning to leave with La Virgen de San Juan de los Lagos after praying to her.\nThe tiny Virgen de la Inmaculada Concepción at display in the Cathedral Basilica was first used by a Fray to convert the indigenous to Catholicism. It is said that a circus gymnast girl once failed a daring pirouette and died a gruesome death, only to be brought back to life by La Virgen.\nYou finally make it past all the other pilgrims and stand in front of her, surrounded by thousands if not millions of Exvotos from previous pilgrims.
Please accept this cute drawing as my thanks, I made it myself!
My things are packed, everything is in order. I will now go to the city that sleeps under the lover volcanoes.
Puebla de los Ángeles

You have made it to the city that was traced by the angels themselves, hence the alternative name “Angelópolis”. The Very Noble, Very Loyal, and Very Heroic city of Puebla has always found a way to be a protagonist in the history of Mexico, and so it is also a protagonist of its religiosity.\nYour first stop is in La Parroquia de los Remedios in which you are greeted by El Cristo de la Bala, who legends tell protected a Mexican hero of old from a treacherous foreigners bullet with his smooth face, bullet that yet remains in the figure. Finally you arrive to the Cathedral Basilica of Puebla and you are amazed by its size and majestuosity. Legends say this design was supposed to be the design for the Cathedral in Mexico City, but somehow the papers got mixed up and Puebla received a magnificent cathedra, thus forcing the church to make an even more majestic one for the capital.\nYou have seen it yourself, the architecture is immaculate.
There is no doubt about it, this city was made by the angels!
My things are packed, everything is in order. I will now journey to the city of churches.
Cholula de San Andrés y San Pedro

You are now arriving to the town of Cholula, famous all across Mexico for the enormous quantity of churches that the city possesses. It is said that a person could attend a different church every single day and not run out of new churches until a year has gone by.\nThe most notable church of them all is El Santuario de Nuestra Señora de los Remedios, built on top of the big hill that overlooks the town. But as you get closer you realise that is no hill, it is actually a semi-buried pyramid, the largest in the entire world in fact.\nYou decide to follow the stone-paved road to the top of the pyramid and enter the beautifully adorned church.
This is a church that is worthy of calling itself the home of Dios!
My things are packed, everything is in order. Now I venture to the rugged hills of Malinalco to get to Chalma.
Chalma

You have finally arrived at your destination after a long journey through the mountains and hills of Malinalco. The town of Chalma may not be very big or seem very important, but since time immemorial this place has been a place of worship.\nFirst the locals worshipped their local idols in the darkness of the caves that are prevalent all around the small township, but when one day some missionaries found a small figure of Jesucristo in the cross in one of the caves, with all the local idols broken at his feet, the people let Dios into their heart and took the figure and named him El Señor de Chalma.\nThe sanctuary may not be the biggest or fanciest in the world, but you feel the peace of Dios while looking at the old temple flanked by the clear waterway that flows beside it.
I shall enter the spring so that El Señor de Chalma may also protect me!
My things are packed, everything is in order. I am ready to walk the bumpy and treacherous roads of Old Veracruz.
Catemaco

You have finally arrived at Catemaco, the realm of La Santa Muerte and sorcery of all kinds. It is a small town on the shore of the lake of the same name and not too far from the coast of the Gulf of Mexico. The roads of Old Veracruz test you with steep mountain passes, deep jungles, and mosquito infested regions, but later rewards you with beautiful scenery of waterways, farmland, the coast and beautiful and tranquil towns, just as how La Santa Muerte can be both beautiful and horrid.\nLegends and myths about Catemaco pale in comparison to the reality, in every street and plaza of the town there is a small multitude waiting to pay a witch for their services, be it a Limpia, an Amarre, or just a simple divination.\nThe town is filled to the brim with the spirit of La Santa Muerte and your mind dwells on the inevitable day in which you will finally meet her in person, just as all other mortals.
I will not leave until I find an available witch to attend me!
My things are packed, everything is in order. As the sick and weary of old, I will make my way to the north.
Espinazo

In the middle of nowhere, between the cities of Saltillo, Piedras Negras, and massive Monterrey, lies the barely inhabited town of Espinazo, birthplace of Fidencismo and final resting place of El Niño Fidencio. The tiny settlement’s population is always at least quintupled every time a large pilgrim group arrives and most of the locals work tending to the needs of the faithful.\nThe town became notorious when Niño Fidencio started to do his miracle works in town, curing illnesses and performing painless surgeries with just fire-treated broken bottles, famously curing one ruler of Old Mexico from his ailments.\nIn the main street lies the church dedicated in his honor and where his bones rest. You enter and see a Cajita being possessed by the spirit of El Niño Fidencio and bathing people in muddy water.
Good thing I brought a towel and a change of clothes!
My things are packed, everything is in order. I will stem the cold tide and visit Ichtus’ natural wonder.
Cabo San Lucas

The southernmost tip of the Baja California peninsula has always received countless visitors to its hot shores but chilly water. Being the point where the Sea of Cortés meets the Pacific Ocean, the ever-constant waves, no doubt with the interference of Icthus himself, have shaped the rocks off the coast creating a beautiful arch, El Arco de Cabo San Lucas.\nBut as Icthus’ wishes his children to become strong and know and rule the waves, the arch, and the minuscule beach underneath it, is always below water except for when the low tide arrives. At the shore one can hire a small boat to ferry you across, but you see some pilgrims save the coin and just make the treacherous swim.\nYou took the middle rout, and rented a small rowboat to get to the arch, and when you step out of it the first thing you see is a tiny seashell and a tiny pearl gleaming in the sands of El Arco de Cabo San Lucas.
This is truly Icthus’ work, I shall make a necklace out of you two!
The Pontifex Maximus

The history of Eastern Christianity has entered a new chapter. [Root.GetTitledName] has declared themselves Pontfex Maximus, asserting that [Root.GetSheHe] has been divinely selected to lead the Christian away from heresy. [Root.GetHerHisCap] claim has been eagerly accepted by all followers of the Latinate.
Latin is the language of God!

Mortification of the Flesh is an act undertaken in order to repent for sins or as a way to share and imitate the Passion of Christ. While the tradition long predates the event, it was only after it that it took the more extreme form practiced by contemporary Penitentes, as instruments of mortification were made bloodier. Penitente Rulers are expected to practice mortification regularly..
I will walk barefoot and wear the Cilice.
This is the most common and riskless form of Penance.
I will publically whip myself using the discipline.
Self-flagellation is seen as very pious, however it also carries more risk than simply wearing the Cilice.
I will imitate His Passion and ask to be put in a Cross.
This is the most extraordinary form of mortification of the flesh, however it also carries higher risk compared to all others.
You spent a long time wearing the Cilice in public, as an act repent and Reparation. It was a painful but rewarding experience.
Pecador Contempla.

Although the original Cilice used in the pre-event world was only meant to cause some discomfort, the ones worn by contemporary Penitentes are meant to cause actual pain and often occasionate bleeding. As you spent a long time wearing the cilice you ended up developing an infection from the wounds it caused. May God take this as an act of repent and Reparation.
Pecador Contempla.

In addition to the chain Cilice, you also had to wear a sackcloth and walk barefoot. While walking through somewhat rough terrain, you ended up wounding your feet, and it later developed into a swollen ankle.
Pecador Contempla.

You practiced mortification through the use of the Penance, a small whip containing seven cords, each representing one of the seven deadly sins as an act repent and Reparation. It was a painful but rewarding experience.

You practiced mortification through the use of the Penance, a small whip containing seven cords, each representing one of the seven deadly sins. The constant self-flagellation opened a wound, and occasionated an infection. May God take this as an act of repent and Reparation.

You practiced mortification through the use of the Penance, a small whip containing seven cords, each representing one of the seven deadly sins. The constant self-flagellation ended leaving you badly bruised. May God take this as an act of repent and Reparation.

You asked to be publically crucified for a few minutes, a form of mortification considered by the Penitentes to be both the most pious and risky. Although it was painful, you did not sustain any serious injuries and it left you with new insight over the Passion of Christ.

You asked to be publically crucified for a few minutes, a form of mortification considered by the Penitentes to be both the most pious and risky. It was a very painful experience as it left you severely injured, but it also gave you new insight over the Passion of Christ.
He underwent all that pain, only to give us a second chance...

You asked to be publically crucified for a few minutes, a form of mortification considered by the Penitentes to be both the most pious and risky. It was a very painful experience as staying in such a position lead to you breaking your ribs, but it also gave you new insight over the Passion of Christ.

You asked to be publically crucified for a few minutes, a form of mortification considered by the Penitentes to be both the most pious and risky. During the re-enactment, you started suffering from severe bleeding. At first everyone thought it to be part of the play only to later realise the bleeding was real and rushing you to a doctor. However it was already too late at that point...
Pecador contempla el dia final.

Your recent mortification of the flesh was a transforming experience for you. Your discipline toughened in response to your physical trauma and you learned to better resist the temptations of the flesh.
I am becoming a better Christian

Penitente rulers are expected to serve as an example to their people and regularly practice Mortification of the Flesh as penance for both his sins and the sins of his people. You however have went too long without performing mortification, which has earned you the disaproval of the clergy.
I should have seen this coming.
Your lack of faith §Rdisturbs§! the Hermano Mayor.
The Prelate Has Had a Vision!

The Prelado of Cristo Rey has announced to the world that he has been blessed with a sacred vision from Our Lady of Guadalupe, igniting within him a profound purpose to embark on a quest of the utmost importance, to which he has solemnly sworn his lifelong dedication. He has scrupulously documented instructions for his most trusted subordinates within the Prelature should he die and leave his mission unfinished. Even now, hundreds of envoys have set out on journeys across the continent in search of something, the specifics of which are being kept in absolute secrecy.
Whatever the Prelado needs, Dios will show him the way.
Has the man succumbed to madness?
I have a bad feeling about this...
Why do I have the sudden urge to dress as a Charro?
As long as they don't bother my realm, the man can do whatever he wants.
The Prelate's Envoy in my Court.

For the past few days, an envoy of the Prelado of Cristo Rey, Nepomuceno Miramón, has been a guest here in the [Title.GetBaseName]. His behavior has been rather peculiar, as he has been inquiring about my family's history with the courtiers and constantly comparing me to a sketch he carries with him at all times. Finally, he requested an audience with me and questioned the reason behind my use of a language that none of my vassals nor neighbors speak. When I explained that it was an old legacy of the family, he became extremely agitated. In a rushed and stuttering manner, he expressed that it was time for him to return to the Prelado, but reassured me not to worry and promised to come back as soon as he could. With a gesture of respect, he kissed my hand, bowed, and bid me farewell as "Su Alteza Imperial."
What's this about “your imperial highness?”. What empire could he possibly mean?
The Prelate Sails Away!

Several days ago, the Cristero leader was observed dashing with a small entourage of militant priest-soldiers, commanded by Bishop Nepomuceno Miramón, towards the port of Manzanillo on the Pacific Coast. Upon their arrival, they promptly chartered a medium-sized ship and swiftly set sail towards the south. The Prelado was last seen waving towards the multitude of people on the pier, shouting, "My destination marks the culmination of my divine mission! If I succeed, it will signify that I have faithfully served Dios and Our Lady of Guadalupe. If I fail... let us pray to Dios that I do not!"
Why such secrecy? We need him here with us as our leader!
He left just like that? That is indeed bizarre.
What's his motive here? He seems to be up to something suspicious...
Is that not the envoy that was at my court a while ago?
Has he, in fact, lost his sanity?
An Offer You Can Refuse.

Nepomuceno Miramón was the first to bow before me, followed by the Prelado. Intrigued by their presence, I inquired about the reason. The Prelado simply responded, "Your Imperial Highness." It was then confirmed: I am of royal lineage, descending from the last Emperor of México prior to the restoration of La República in ancient times, before the Event.\n"The Virgin of Guadalupe has compelled me to seek you out," declared the Prelado. "you must reclaim your rightful throne and restore México to its sacred oaths." He continued, "All we ask is that, after recovering your birthright, you reinstate the Prelature of Cristo Rey as the final arbiter in the matters of the one true faith. I will lend my support through the militant wing of my order and rally independent Cristero lords to pledge their loyalty to you. Miramón will remain here, assisting you in organizing for the impending invasion, which is planned to commence in approximately two years. So, will you heed the call of Dios and Our Lady of Guadalupe and assist us in our holy mission?"
¡Por Dios, que sí! ¡Viva México!
You shall abandon your realm and embark on an adventure to the §GMexican Empire§!
I am honored, but I will decline this offer.
The Prelate and Miramón will be §Rdisappointed§! with you.
I should just arrest these madmen!.
You will arrest both the Prelate and Miramón and turn them in to the Benemérito.
The Failure of a Prelate.

Today, Prelado [the_prelate.GetFirstName] and Commander-Bishop Nepomuceno Miramón have made a solemn announcement. They revealed that, regrettably, their divine mission to defend Mexico from what they perceive as heresy has ended in failure, primarily due to the perceived treachery of a foreign figure known as Justo Armas. As a result, they have decided to step down from their esteemed positions.\nThe newly appointed leader of the Cristeros, Prelado [d_cristo_rey.Holder.GetFirstName], has tasked them with a new mission: a journey to Brazil. Their objective is to establish an ecumenical dialogue with the great southern empire and implore its emperor to renounce any heretical beliefs.\nThe faithful Cristeros find themselves bewildered by this turn of events. The nature of the conspiracy has caused many to question their faith in the prelature as an institution. Whispers of heresy have even begun to emerge, further exacerbating the uncertainty among the devoted followers.
The Prelado is certainly fallible, this confirms it.
Cristo Rey get §R-15 Moral Authority§! for 10 years
I guess there was nothing to worry about after all.
Did they really call me out as a coward? I was nice to them!
So… who is this Justo Armas and why is he a coward?
A Monarchist Conspiracy Foiled!

I have received crucial information from the foreign individual, [el_justo.GetTitle] Justo Armas, shedding light on a grave matter. It has come to my attention that the Prelado of Cristo Rey and one of his commander-bishops were engaged in a meticulously planned conspiracy. Their objective was to orchestrate an attack on La República by attempting to recruit Justo Armas and rallying independent Cristero lords, with the ultimate goal of dethroning me and restoring Cristero dominion over México. Today, I hold the two imprisoned conspirators in my custody, and it falls upon me to decide their fates. What punishment should be meted out for their audacious attempt to wage war against La República?
¡Mátalos en caliente! The Cristeros shall pay for this treachery!
Will start a §Rwar§! over El Bajío
I can ransom the religious leader, but the soldier shall die.
Más vale mal conocido que bueno por conocer, release them.
The Eagle's Vengeance

The Benemérito of México, has announced that the Prelado of Cristo Rey and his accomplice, Nepomuceno Miramón, were both found guilty of conspiring to make war on La República by attempting to recruit a foreigner by the name of Justo Armas and install him as Emperor. After the sentencing, both men were fusilladed with crossbows. The Benemérito also claims that the neighboring Cristero realms in El Bajío were implicated in this conspiracy and therefore will pay in time.\nMeanwhile, the Cristeros condemned the executions, claiming their deaths as martyrdom. The outrage generated by the Benemérito's actions has increased the fervor of the Cristeros and eclipsed the failure of the Prelature in their sacred mission. The conflict between Sagrado Corazón and Cristo Rey for the soul of Mexico is just beginning.
We shall never submit! ¡Viva Cristo Rey!
Cristo Rey gets §G+10 Moral Authority§! for 30 years
Damn those Cristeros, they bring nothing but chaos!
Ni perdón, ni olvido. Down with the traitors!
We should prepare for the incoming onslaught.
That isn’t my fault, how could I have known it would end like this?
Wait, they still fusillade people over there? How barbaric!
Justicia Mexicana

The ruler of Mexico, Benemérito [e_mexico.Holder.GetBestName], has made a grave announcement, revealing the guilt of the Prelado of the Prelature of Cristo Rey and his commander-bishop Nepomuceno Miramón in a conspiracy to wage war against La República. Their plot involved recruiting a foreign individual named Justo Armas, with the intention of installing him as Emperor. Following their sentencing, Miramón faced immediate execution by fusillade of crossbow bolts, his naked body hung and displayed in Iztapalapa, while the Prelado was imprisoned and held on ransom.\nThe Cristeros, deeply outraged by the humiliation endured by their prelature and the failure in their divine mission, have witnessed the Prelado [the_prelate.GetFirstName] stepping down from his position. He has chosen exile, engaging in missionary work in Brazil. Now, the new Prelado, [d_cristo_rey.Holder.GetFirstName], faces the daunting task of healing a community that has been deeply wounded, where whispers of heresy grow louder and bolder by the day.
It is time to focus on more pressing matters.
Surely everything will work out in the end, right?
Wait, they still fusillade people over there? How barbaric!
Mercy for the Humiliated

The Benemérito of Mexico has made a surprising announcement, declaring that both the Prelado and his commander-bishop, Nepomuceno Miramón, have been granted pardons for the alleged crime of waging war against La República. The justification behind this decision lies in the fact that the testimonial evidence provided by a treacherous foreign noble named Justo Armas, who implicated them, is deemed untrustworthy due to his reputation as a coward.\nHaving regained their freedom, the Prelado and the Commander-bishop lamented the unfortunate news that their divine mission entrusted to the Prelature by Dios and the Virgen de Guadalupe has met failure, primarily due to the cowardice of Justo Armas. Consequently, they have chosen to step down from their esteemed positions. The new Prelado of the Cristeros has assigned them to engage in missionary work in Brazil, while he endeavors to mitigate the repercussions of this humiliating ordeal on the Prelature of Cristo Rey.
Great! Now no one will ever trust me again!
Boo! Where’s the violence?
The Pope’s Man

A mysterious man sought an audience with me concerning the imminent invasion of Mexico. The meeting took place in a secluded location, far from the presence of my courtiers, with only Miramón and myself accompanying the exiled nobleman from Lousiane, Henri Ledonnant.\nHe had been dispatched by the Pope in St. Louis to offer support for my expedition. Nepomuceno Miramón questioned their motives, and Ledonnant explained that St. Louis had been aware of my lineage for centuries, and now they desired to see the rightful Emperor ascend the Mexican throne. His sole request was for me to secure a coastal county in the Gulf of Mexico during the invasion, enabling his troops to safely land.\nI sought Miramón's counsel, as he harbored reservations toward envoys from the heretic Gringo Pope, but ultimately left the decision in my hands.
We welcome you and your men into our cause.
Henri Ledonnant becomes the ruler of a mercenary band called §GCatholic Friends of Mexico§!
I neither want, nor need, the help of some distant heretical “Pope”.
Echoes of an Old Name
Whispers of an Old Name

After a two-month absence, the Prelado has returned to his entourage with great jubilation, proclaiming the success of his divine mission and emphasizing the need for preparedness as the appointed time approaches. Interestingly, in St. Louis, the Pope himself has been observed in a joyous state, even hosting a lavish banquet for an exiled noble named Henri Ledonnant, who has been recruiting adventurers for a mysterious purpose since his return from foreign lands.\nAmidst the veil of secrecy and uncertainty, one consistent rumor has emerged—the significance of September 2670. While the exact meaning remains elusive, everyone is now making plans in anticipation of whatever event unfolds on that momentous date.

:After a two-month voyage, the Prelado has returned with his entourage, exuding immense joy and declaring the successful completion of his divine mission according to plan. He emphasized the need to now prepare for the forthcoming time.\n Interestingly, in St. Louis, the Pope's mood was strikingly different, as he publicly chastised an exiled Creole noble named Henri Ledonnant, attributing his actions to a failure and a substantial loss for Catholicism. The exact meaning behind the Pope's words remains uncertain, but the magnitude of his reaction suggests its significance for the leader of the Catholic faithful.\n Amidst the prevailing secrecy and confusion, only one rumor persists with consistency—September 2670. Despite the elusive understanding of its importance, everyone has commenced making preparations for whatever events may unfold when that time arrives.
We should prepare, in any moment the Prelado may ask for our assistance.
We should prepare for Cristero aggression.
Summon my commanders, it is time to prepare for our defense.
I will be ready to seize my rightful throne!
We should prepare, in any moment the Pope may ask for a donation.
Whatever it is, it seems we will not be a part of it. Maybe for the best.
Are the Cristeros and Catholics working together? That cannot be good.
We do live indeed in some interesting times.
The Prelate Asks for your Support

I have received a letter from Prelado [the_prelate.GetFirstName], in which he humbly seeks my assistance in fulfilling the most holy mission that the Prelature of Cristo Rey have promised to the Virgin of Guadalupe. He expresses that the specific details of this mission cannot be revealed at this moment, as the timing is crucial, but assures me that Dios will graciously reward me in this life or the next for my support. Prelado [the_prelate.GetFirstName] welcomes donations in the form of coin, soldiers, or heartfelt oaths of fealty.
I shall donate to the Prelate’s coffers.
The [Root.RelHead.GetTitle] shall §Glift your excommunication§! by virtue of your aid.
I shall send a company of volunteers to serve the Prelature.
We shall send some troops to aid the §Y[Root.RelHead.GetTitle]§!
I shall send a small army led by my best commander.
I swear I will be forever loyal to… whatever the Prelate says I must be loyal to.
You shall join Justo Armas as an ally in the war when the invasion starts and if he wins you shall be vassalized by him
Maybe later, I have more urgent things to do than to help the Prelate in his mission…
You will have the possibility of helping the Prelate later.
The Need for More Dorados

It has become evident that La República is facing the threat of attacks from both known traitors and as yet undiscovered foes. Although our armies may be substantial enough to overcome any potential adversaries, it would be prudent to reinforce our ranks by recruiting additional men. I have instructed my advisors and El Congreso to present me with options for fortifying our defense.
Now, what do we need the most?
New decisions to §Gaid in the defense§! will be available to you
Catholic Friends of Mexico Ask for a Donation

I have granted Henri Ledonnant an audience at my court, where he beseeches, on behalf of Pope [Root.RelHead.GetFirstName], my aid in a remarkably audacious expedition aimed at spreading the faith. He assures me that assisting in this endeavor will earn me great favor with Our Lord, though he cryptically refrains from disclosing the precise destination of his divine mission. However, the name of his company gives me a clue.\nHenri Ledonnant welcomes contributions in the form of monetary donations or the provision of soldiers.
I shall donate to their coffers.
I shall send a company of volunteers to serve the faith.
I shall send a small army led by my best commander.
Maybe later, I have more urgent things to do...
You will have the possibility of helping the Friends of Mexico later.
Justo Armas!

After meticulous years of covert planning, Justo Armas has launched his expedition to wage war on Mexico and its Benemérito, with the aim of reclaiming the throne that rightfully belongs to him as the descendant of the last Emperor of Mexico, predating the restoration of La República centuries ago.\nThe leader of the Prelature of Cristo Rey has rallied behind Justo Armas' call to arms, declaring that their prelature was entrusted with the mission of winning back the soul of Mexico by La Virgen de Guadalupe long ago. Additionally, the Pope in St. Louis has provided his support by authorizing the expedition of the Catholic Friends of Mexico to those ancient lands.\nUndoubtedly, the impending war will be marked by bloodshed and formidable challenges for Justo Armas and his courageous commanders, Nepomuceno Miramón and Henri Ledonnant. However, the prize of the Mexican throne is unquestionably worth the risk they are undertaking.

After meticulous years of covert planning, Justo Armas has launched his expedition to wage war on Mexico and its Benemérito, with the aim of reclaiming the throne that rightfully belongs to him as the descendant of the last Emperor of Mexico, predating the restoration of La República centuries ago.\nThe leader of the Prelature of Cristo Rey has rallied behind Justo Armas' call to arms, declaring that their prelature was entrusted with the mission of winning back the soul of Mexico by La Virgen de Guadalupe long ago.\nUndoubtedly, the impending war will be marked by bloodshed and formidable challenges for Justo Armas and his courageous commanders, Nepomuceno Miramón and Henri Ledonnant. However, the prize of the Mexican throne is unquestionably worth the risk they are undertaking.
¡Viva Cristo Rey!
¡Justo Armas y su banda serán hechos justos por las armas!
I am no longer the owner of my life, it belongs to the people of Mexico!
§RYOU MUST SIEGE DOWN A COASTAL PROVINCE IN ORDER TO RECEIVE THE AID OF THE FRIENDS OF MEXICO§!
Deus Vult!
How can this be? Are the history books wrong?
Death of a Commander-Bishop

Justo Armas, the foreign pretender fighting to seize to the Mexican Throne, has suffered a significant setback. Benemérito [e_mexico.Holder.GetFirstName] has announced that the Commander-Bishop Nepomuceno Miramón is now dead, thus depriving Justo Armas and his Cristero allies of one of their most trusted commanders in the war.
He died a martyr as he died fighting for his faith!
Good riddance.
So long my friend, you will be sorely missed.
Surely this will turn the tide of the war.
Death of a Prelate

Justo Armas, the foreign pretender vying for the Mexican Throne, has encountered a significant setback. Benemérito [e_mexico.Holder.GetBaseName] has made the announcement of the demise of the Prelate of Cristo Rey, [d_cristo_rey.Holder.GetBestName], thereby depriving Justo Armas of one of his most influential allies and causing a leadership vacuum within the Prelature of Cristo Rey.
Death of a Benemérito

La República has suffered a significant setback in its defense against the foreign pretender, Justo Armas. El Congreso has officially confirmed the death of Benemérito [dead_benemerito.GetFirstName]. This loss of leadership will undoubtedly hinder the Mexican armies in these critical times of war, until the new ruler settles into the Silla Presidencial.
Good riddance.
No time to mourn, we have a war to win.
I inch ever closer to victory!
Surely this will turn the tide of the war.
The Friends Arrive

A beach along the Gulf of Mexico has transformed into a bustling military camp, as several hundred merchant ships and fishing boats harbor Henri Ledonnant's volunteer Catholic Company, known as The Catholic Friends of Mexico. With their improvised fleet set sail, these brave volunteers, led by their captain, must now unite with Justo Armas in his quest for the throne and confront the formidable armies of the Mexican Benemérito.
My friend and his army will prove decisive in this war.
Excellent, some much needed reinforcements.
These men have just sealed their death sentences.
Great, even more foreign invaders to prolong this unnecessary war...
Death of a Friend

Justo Armas, the foreign pretender striving to claim the Mexican Throne, has experienced a significant setback. Benemérito [e_mexico.GetFullName] has declared the demise of Henri Ledonnant, the captain of The Catholic Friends of Mexico, thereby stripping Justo Armas of one of his most influential allies and dealing a severe blow to the volunteer Catholic military company.
So long my friend, you will be sorely missed.
We have lost a commander, but not yet the war.
Good riddance.
Excellent, one less foreign invader to kill.
Death of a Pretender
It is over
column3: he has failed. Across Old Mexico, the resounding words of the ruler of La República, Benemérito [e_mexico.Holder.GetFirstName], have been heard. Justo Armas has met his end by the sword, his ill-conceived expedition to conquer the Mexican Throne proving to be his final folly. With the death of their leader, his armies have scattered, and his allies have returned to their homes. There is nothing left to be done.\nIt appears that the blood of the last emperor of ancient Mexico once again faltered against La República that resisted and ousted it from Chapultepec Castle in the times of legend.

column2: We have been defeated, retreat!
La República was once restored in ancient times, now I have strengthened it with this victory!
Justo Armas may be dead, but his blood and dream of empire yet live.
Once more, the ancient empire survives...
Su Alteza Imperial

Justo Armas has accomplished the seemingly impossible: he has emerged victorious over the Mexican Benemérito and assumed complete control of La República.\nIn a scene filled with profound emotion, the Prelado, accompanied by the Cristero leaders, entered the Basílica de Guadalupe, where tears of joy streamed down their faces as they stood before the revered image of the Virgin of the Tepeyac, declaring that their divine mission was was once again upheld. Curiously, The Catholic Friends of Mexico were spotted leisurely strolling through the wooded paths of Chapultepec Forest, still adorned in their armor. Unverified reports suggest that they have taken control of several port towns in Veracruz...\nAs of now, the triumphant Justo Armas and his allies will gather at Chapultepec Castle to address minor matters before orchestrating a grand victory parade.
Justo Armas Victorious

Justo Armas has accomplished the seemingly impossible: he has emerged victorious over the Mexican Benemérito and assumed complete control of La República.\nIn a scene filled with profound emotion, the Prelado, accompanied by the Cristero leaders, entered the Basílica de Guadalupe, where tears of joy streamed down their faces as they stood before the revered image of the Virgin of the Tepeyac, declaring that their divine mission was was once again upheld.\nAs of now, the triumphant Justo Armas and his allies will gather at Chapultepec Castle to address minor matters before orchestrating a grand victory parade.
¡Viva Cristo Rey!
Let us see if this Justo Armas resists the pressure of that most ancient chair and sash...
Just one more meeting friends and allies, then we shall feast!
Deus Vult!
Justo Armas won? A surprise to be sure, but I do not know if it is a welcome one.
With Friends Like These…

In the gardens of Chapultepec, my Cristero allies and the leaders of The Catholic Friends of Mexico have convened for a significant conference on matters of faith. The Prelate, with utmost politeness, questioned whether the time had arrived for my swearing into the Prelature of of Cristo Rey. The Convlavist Catholic leader interjected, claiming that the Pope sanctioned their expedition with the understanding that I would convert to St. Louis Catholicism following my triumph, or alternatively compensate them generously in gold, or else they would seize control of Mexico themselves.
A Promise to Keep

On a splendid morning in Mexico City, amidst the captivating gardens of Chapultepec, I find myself surrounded by my loyal Cristero allies who have gathered here for a momentous conference centered around matters of faith. All eyes, particularly those of the Prelado, are filled with anticipation, eager to finally hear my stance on the topic of my induction into their prelature, which had been temporarily set aside as we focused on the exigencies of war. With utmost politeness, the Prelado ventured to request my swearing to the prelature in the name of Cristo Rey. In response, the Cristero lords sternly asserted their readiness to instigate a rebellion should I fail to fulfill my promise of incorporation. Such a threat incensed my personal guard, and in the blink of an eye, the serene ambiance descended into complete pandemonium, with both the Cristeros and my guards unsheathing their swords.\nIn a resolute tone, I raised my voice, demanding immediate silence and restoration of order.
¡Viva México! ¡Viva Cristo Rey!
The §MFriends of Mexico§! §Roccupy§! Veracruz! This looks like trouble...
Ave Mexicum! Deus Vult!
The Friends of Mexico will be turned into the §Gelite guard§! of [Root.PrimaryTitle.GetFOA]
The Prelate §Rwill not be pleased§!...
I bow to none of you! Hail Justo Armas!
I do not bow to you! Hail Justo Armas!
El Justo Cristero

All across the Valley of Mexico, and resonating throughout the entire realm, the words of the Mexican Benemérito, Justo Armas, reverberate: “¡Viva México! ¡Viva Cristo Rey!” In a grand ceremony, the Cristero lords and members of the Prelature of Cristo Rey solemnly unveiled the Tricolor band, and with tears in his eyes, the Prelate placed it across Justo Armas’ torso. "We have truly honored our mission to Nuestra Señora de Guadalupe," the Prelate declared, embracing the newly installed Benemérito.
Maybe we should reconsider our allegiance and rejoin Mexico.
¡Viva Cristo Rey! ¡Viva Justo Armas!
This is not good, if even Mexico can fall so can everyone else.
We should begin to organize a resistance to possible oppression.
¡Un laurel para mi de victoria! ¡Un sepulcro para ellos de honor!
An interesting development…
¡Viva Cristo Rey!

The blood of the Last Emperor of Old Mexico, the blood of Justo Armas, has once more fled from Mexico southwards towards El Salvador after having his loyalist forces destroyed by the combined might of the armies of the Prelado and his allied Cristero vassals.\nThe head of the Cristero faithful has now taken the role of kingmaker, choosing the most powerful and pious Cristero in the entirety of Old Mexico to be the new Benemérito and restore Cristo Rey to his rightful place. Whomever he chooses, he is certain he has now fulfilled his mission to La Virgen de Guadalupe.
I waited 800 years for this opportunity… ¡Carajo!
Maybe we should reconsider our allegiance to Mexico City…
¡Viva el Benemérito! ¡Viva Cristo Rey!
We should prepare for any sort of Cristero repression.
So it was all just a coup with extra steps, no?
The Foreign Benemérito

Following a series of decisive victories against the combined forces of the Prelature of Cristo Rey and rebellious vassals, Justo Armas now stands as the unequivocal ruler of La República, uncontested and untethered by any opposition or attempts at control.\nThis marks the second time the Prelature has been compelled to flee from Mexico, yet it is the first occasion they have suffered such a resounding defeat in war. The once-proud Cristeros find themselves engulfed in a deep sense of disillusionment, having failed the sacred mission entrusted to them by La Virgen de Guadalupe so many years ago.
Why has Dios forsaken us?
Yo encarno a la patria y al pueblo bueno.
If he can withstand such immense adversity, we are powerless to overcome him...
Justo Armas truly is a force to be reckoned with…
A Man of His Word

From the halls of Chapultepec Castle, Justo Armas has proclaimed an end to the treachery of the Catholic Friends of Mexico, promising the long-awaited peace that the people of La República yearn for. Spontaneous celebrations have erupted in major cities, particularly in the liberated port city of Veracruz, which has been granted its republican charter once again.\nIn stark contrast, within the ancient walls of Lecumberri prison, Justo Armas presides over the execution of those he once considered allies and friends. The solemnity hangs heavy in the air.\nJusto Armas has made a solemn commitment to the Prelate, vowing to put himself and his realm under the guidance of the Prelature of Cristo Rey. The new Benemérito of La República stands by his word, commanding both respect and uncertainty.
¡Viva México!
Long have we waited for this day!
Such a waste of good men! God will not be pleased…
Does this mean we will finally have peace?
A ruler than can keep his word? I thought that was a myth!
Benemérito Prelado

The blood of the last emperor of ancient Mexico, the blood of Justo Armas, has once more fled south to El Salvador after his loyalist forces were destroyed by the combined might of the armies of the Prelado and his allied Cristero vassals. \nAt the same time, seeing no further way to achieve their victory, the Catholic Friends of Mexico have completely withdrawn from the ancient realm.\nIn order to ensure a swift and peaceful transition, the Prelado of Cristo Rey will take over the rulership of La República until his death, he will attempt to reestablish Cristero control of the realm as it once was and ensure the fulfilment of the sacred mission entrusted to Cristeros by La Virgen de Guadalupe.
¡Viva el Benemérito Prelado! ¡Viva Cristo Rey!
The Church controlling La República? It should be the other way around!
It seems Deus did not Vult…
A Prelate as king? Now that is a ridiculous idea!
The Conqueror of Mexico

The roads on the Mexican frontier and the ports in the Mexican coasts are filled to the brim by fleeing soldiers in battered armor. Cristeros and Catholics alike have been soundly defeated by the foreign conqueror of La República, Justo Armas.
It seems our endeavours were not favoured by God…
The Latino Emperor

Not since the times before the Event has the Catholic Pope set foot in Mexico, but this was for a special occasion—the proper coronation of Justo Armas.\nAfter the defeat of the Cristeros, the Prelate of Cristo Rey once again fled, and the lands of all rebelling Cristero vassals have been distributed to the commanders who initially invaded with Henri Ledonnant. Now, the army has been reorganized into the Emperor’s personal guard, El Santo Oficio.\nThe era of "La República" is over and all Mexicans have finally been forced to confront this truth. The birth of this new "Latino Empire" heralds a new age, firmly grounded in the divine right of kings, and sanctified by the Pope himself. Justo Armas ascended to the throne, embodying the sacred authority entrusted by a higher power. As the Pope proclaimed during the coronation, "¡México siempre fiel!" - "Ever faithful Mexico!", the significance of the new empire, built upon the foundations of divine sovereignty, resonated throughout the land. Where the old empire was governed by a cacique, the Latino Empire stands as a testament to sacred sovereignty and the unyielding belief in the divine mandate.
No! How could things have gone so wrong?
The throne of the Empress of the Americas is reclaimed. Deus Vult!
La República will be reorganised into the §GFirst Latino Empire§!
The Mexican Empire will be replaced by the Latino Empire.
¡Pobre México! ¡Tan lejos de Dios y tan cerca de gringos!
Is this it? Is this how Mexico finally ends?
Not Latino but indeed an Empire

The bloodline of the last emperor of ancient Mexico, Justo Armas, has once again retreated to El Salvador, as his loyalist forces were decimated by the cunning adventurers comprising the Catholic Friends of Mexico. The Prelate of Cristo Rey was compelled to flee, while the Catholics seized all Cristero lands and redistributed them among their now feuding commanders. The ensuing chaos forced the Pope to journey southward, issuing a decree that abolished La República and established a feudal Latino Empire. Additionally, the Catholic Friends of Mexico were disbanded, giving rise to El Santo Oficio, a special body under the Emperor's control. \nWhile the foreign rulers now governing the former Mexico rejoice in the Pope's decrees, native Mexicans harbor discontent. The prospect of further conflicts looms on the horizon...
Mexico is not yet dead, it lives in every single one of us!
The Reconciliation of [Root.GetTitledFirstName]

Though [Root.GetSheHe] rose to power as an outsider without the express approval of the previous ruler, [Root.GetTitledFirstName] has shrewdly been able to assert [Root.GetHerHim]self as the new political establishment in México. The halls of power have been reshaped, and a new era has begun, characterized by the rise of [Root.GetTitledFirstName] and [Root.GetHerHis] iron-fisted grip on La República's political landscape. [Root.GetTitledFirstName]'s ascent to power was marked by an unwavering ambition, exploiting the weaknesses and divisions within the ruling elite. With a calculated strategy and a cunning political mind, [Root.GetTitledFirstName] skillfully outmaneuvered [Root.GetHisHer] opponents, silencing dissent and consolidating [Root.GetHisHer] control over the levers of power. Through a combination of manipulation, coercion, and an unyielding determination, [Root.GetTitledFirstName] has emerged as the sole arbiter of México's political destiny.
I have the reins of power in my hands.
Long live the [Root.PrimaryTitle.GetRulerTitle]!
We shall see
I will submit to your will.
